posts.name: ChipBergquist
posts.cooked:
What does PhotonUtils.estimateFieldToRobotAprilTag() consider to be the origin of the robot?

The only reference I can find, anywhere, of the definition of the origin of the robot is here:

Coordinate systems are used in FRC programming in several places. A few of the common places are: robot movement, joystick input, pose estimation, AprilTags, and path planning. It is important to u...

Where they discuss it in terms of the kinematics system. Several sources talk about the coordinate system used. And they all agree, but this is the only reference to the origin, and I do not think it is being used consistently.

This line of code:

private Transform3d cameraToRobotTransform = new Transform3d( 0, 0, 0, new Rotation3d( 0, 0, 0 ) );

Puts the camera at the origin of the robot, correct?

When used here:

And shown on the dashboard with this command

It seems to be saying my robot‚Äôs origin is on one of the corners of the robot, not in the center of the robot.

link_counts.title: Coordinate System ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: So where is your camera w.r.t. the center of the robot? Your code says it is at x,y origin, but on the carpet. If the camera really is near one corner, then that is what you will see in the computed Pose

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
The javadoc is pretty clear, it‚Äôs the center of your robot. image 1040√ó82 5.42 KB

image 1040√ó82 5.42 KB

image 1040√ó82 5.42 KB

Yes, the link is broken, the coordinate system documentation was updated this year. This figure from the new page shows the robot origin in the 3D coordinate system.

posts.name: ChipBergquist
posts.cooked:
My initial reaction was, it doesn‚Äôt matter when the camera is, I told the software it was in the middle. Yes, it was my intent to say it was in the middle, on the carpet. My ‚Äúrobot‚Äù is essentially a RoboRio, Orange Pi, and Camera with a power supply. It is a test bench for learning about vision programming.

But your question made me realize something. The Smart Dashboard is showing me a representation of my robot that is clearly an assumption on its part. I have not checked the actual data in the robotPose3d. That may be exactly what I expect and it is just the display on the Smart Dashboard that is ‚Äúwrong‚Äù. I will head back to the lab and also put the details of the final field pose explicitly on the dashboard and see if the two representations agree.

posts.name: ChipBergquist
posts.cooked:
The link is broken? Odd, not for me. Yes, I saw this diagram, that is what confused me.

Yes, this clearlt states it. I had not found it yet: /**>

I will verify that the Pose returned by this is what I expected and just the presentation of the field on Smart Dashboard is what is off.

Thanks guys!

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: The link redirects, and it‚Äôs not to a ‚Äúrobot coordinate system‚Äù section of the docs, but the info is on the page.
